This supported speculation of possible decline in severity with the advent of 28 warmer spring and summer temperatures in north-temperate latitudes (Sajadi et al., 29 2020; Wang et al., 2020) , comparable to many viruses affecting human respiratory systems, 30 including SARS (Tan et al., 2005; Gaunt et al., 2010) . 31

However, recent (updated up to March 26, 2020; cf. Methods) data revealed the 32 spread of the epidemic across territories experiencing warm temperatures in the tropics (e.g. 33

Indonesia, Singapore, Brazil) and southern hemisphere as well (e.g. Australia, Argentina). 34

The current distribution of the epidemic challenges, therefore, the inference that SARS-CoV-35 2 may behave as a seasonal respiratory virus based on previous statistical analyses from 36 earlier realized distributions. 37

Our updated results (Figure 1) show, however, that 110 this apparent temperature-dependence was confounded with a prevailing zonal pattern of 111 spread across the north-temperate zone, possibly reflecting the main patterns of human 112 mobility, which delayed arrival of the epidemics to the southern hemisphere and the tropics. 113

These results suggest that, contrary to prior assessments, the spread rate of the 115 COVID-19 pandemic is temperature-independent, suggesting that there is little hope for relief 116 as temperatures in the northern hemisphere increase, and that poor nations with weak health 117 systems in tropical regions, such as African, are at great risk. 118
